title: Plan to ease gridlock near NAS Pensacola includes park, bike lanes and turnaround lane
description: Escambia County is finalizing plans for South Navy Boulevard, which includes features to beautify the area and reduce traffic gridlock.
content:
As many as a thousand cars a day are turned away at the front gate of Naval Air Station Pensacola when visitors realize they can’t access the base from South Navy Boulevard.

It’s a problem not only for the drivers who must maneuver to turn around, but also for base security.

The gatekeepers are often left dealing with long lines of traffic as they sort through who can enter, which contributes to traffic jams and speeding on S. Navy Boulevard when drivers jockey to get a better spot in line and wait their turn.

Escambia County’s proposed South Navy Boulevard Improvement plan maps out a solution for the problem – a turnaround feature, like a round-a-bout, at the foot of Sam Lovelace Bridge which leads directly to the base’s front entrance.

It’s an important part of the plan to improve South Navy Boulevard that aims to address blight and traffic problems, as well as build up the Warrington community and support the mission of NAS Pensacola.

“Base leaders are very interested in the turnaround aspect at the south end of the project where they have numerous people heading towards the base, realizing they can't get on the base, and then it's a procedure to make them turn around,” Escambia Development Program Manager for the Warrington District Max Rogers said.

Rogers said installing the turnaround at the end of South Navy Boulevard along with variable message signs along the road informing people of who can enter NAS Pensacola from the main gate, gives drivers the opportunity to turn around without jamming the entrance.

What improvements are planned for S. Navy Blvd.

It’s one of many new features of Escambia County’s South Navy Boulevard Improvement Plan - Preferred Alternative, the final version of the plan created after months of design and citizen input.

The last public input meeting on the plan was held at Lexington Terrace in Warrington on Aug. 28, but people can still comment and weigh in on it online at southnavyblvd.com/about/.

Across from the proposed turnaround, the county is also planning to create a public park on vacant property along Bayou Grande.

Boost for base: Wanted: Your input on Escambia County's plans for S. Navy Blvd. in Warrington

Rogers said the county partnered with the U.S. Navy several years ago to purchase the waterfront lots with the goal of zero development.

“Our military bases are always concerned about encroachment of development,” Rogers said of the park. “People already go down there and view the sunset, and we took some good public input and we're proposing to add a couple parallel parking spaces. It'll allow people to legally park there and enjoy the park, and when they're ready to leave, they can just get in the turnaround and head on back.”

The improvement covers the last mile for South Navy Boulevard from Gulf Beach Highway to NAS Pensacola.

Other proposed improvements include eliminating the third lane that opens on South Navy Boulevard. as drivers leave the base and come off the Sam Lovelace Bridge.

The county wants to turn that additional lane into a 10-foot wide, shared-use path for bikes and pedestrians.

There will also be sidewalks and the placement of medians in the center of the road with trees planted at pedestrian crossings.

What neighbors have to say about the final plan

Navy Point resident Cathryn Holley and her husband attended the county’s final public input meeting on the improvement plan. Holley likes what she sees for the most part but supports even more changes that would discourage speeding.

“We like the whole area, but we just want to slow the traffic down,” Holley said. “They're going too fast. You should see some of the accidents. They are horrific.”

Jim Kauffman said the project is “definitely needed.” He said the main road leading to the base has been overdue for a makeover since he first moved to the area more than 20 years ago.

“I noticed that going into the base wasn't as pretty as a lot of the main roads going into other military bases,” Kaufmann said. “But now the county’s putting the effort into making some green belts along the middle, installing sidewalks, and new flowers, new crosswalks. I think it's going to be safer. I'm very excited.”

Improvements aimed at cutting down on speeding and accidents, as well as maximizing landscaping are top priorities of the plan, which was created with a lot of public input.

County staff said they received 657 completed surveys, tallied 2,932 website sessions and saw 118 people who came to the first workshop in May.

Navarro Jackson is president of the Warrington Neighborhood Watch, and he’s happy to see positive development in the area, which is also beset with issues like poverty, crime and homelessness.

“This area needs some beautification,” Jackson said. “Our men in uniform, when they come and go from that base, they deserve to see good things, not bad things.”

What's next for the S. Navy Blvd. improvement plan

County staff say they plan to bring the project for final approval to the Escambia Board of County Commissioners in October.

They also need approval from the Florida Department of Transportation to repurpose the traffic lane. Once that is complete, the plan will enter the engineering design phase, which may take a year or longer to finish.

The county is casting a wide net to fund the multi-million-dollar project including pursuing RESTORE Act funds, Department of Defense grants and state funding.

In July, the U.S. House of Representatives approved $3 million for improvements to South Navy Boulevard.

“It's a great project,” Rogers said. “I think it's a good step forward to try to address issues. It is a blighted corridor. If we improve the area, it can bring businesses to it. Sometimes it's a, ‘Who comes first, the chicken or the egg?’ Is it the private sector or the government bringing the infrastructure? I think by bringing this project, it will motivate and encourage new businesses.”

Sheila Feltner agrees the project will bring up the entire community.

“I'm excited for the west side of Pensacola, not only for the base, but also for the neighborhood and for new business and for people to be outside in the park they’re putting in,” Feltner said. “I see it as a real plus for all of us, not just the base.”

This article originally appeared on Pensacola News Journal: Escambia proposes turnaround, public park for S. Navy Blvd. plan

Create a plan that improves mobility and safety for all modes of travel, enhances landscaping, and addresses lighting along the South Navy Boulevard (SR 295) one-mile corridor, from Barrancas Avenue southward to the deck of the Sam A. Lovelace Bridge.
12-months | September 2024 – August 2025
The South Navy Blvd project is a collaborative process, involving many local partners and stakeholders. It was initiated by Commissioner Mike Kohler, Escambia County Board of County Commission District 2. Escambia County Traffic and Transportation is the lead department and serves as the project management team. Collaborative partners include Naval Air Station Pensacola, Escambia County Community Redevelopment Agency, Escambia County Planning Department, the Florida Department of Transportation, and the Emerald Coast Regional Council.
Beginning with the construction of the Pensacola Navy Yard in 1826, Pensacola NAS has played an integral part in US naval operations for close to 200 years. Pensacola NAS is accessed through its main gate from the north by South Navy Boulevard. Thousands of naval aviators, support personnel, civilian contractors, government and civilian dignitaries, and civilian contractors and tourists have entered the installation along South Navy Boulevard. The corridor from Barrancas Avenue southward to the bridge crossing Bayou Grande into the front gate is a dated, 6-lane asphalt road with two lanes southbound, three lanes northbound, and a center dual left turn lane. There are sidewalks throughout the corridor recently completed on both sides of the roadway through an FDOT resurfacing project. There are no bike lanes. Driveways line both sides of the corridor, many of which do not meet spacing or width standards to foster safe movements to and from the South Navy corridor. There is very little street lighting, typically only a single light at the intersections and the three signalized intersections of Barrancas, Winthrop, and Sunset. A plan is needed to review the corridor through the lenses of access management, safety, and beautification for drivers and pedestrians.

argos_summary: Escambia County’s South Navy Boulevard Improvement plan proposes a turnaround at the base’s front gate, a public park, bike lanes, and enhanced lighting to ease traffic congestion and improve safety for drivers, pedestrians, and cyclists. The project, backed by federal, state, and DoD funds, aims to repurpose a third lane into a shared path, add sidewalks, and install variable message signs to guide access to NAS Pensacola. Public input and a July $3 million House allocation support the plan, with final approval slated for October 2024 and engineering design to follow. The initiative seeks to reduce gridlock, lower speeding, and beautify the corridor while supporting local economic development.
